Thank you Felipe for your answer!

Le lun. 4 juin 2018 =C3=A0 7:53 PM, Feli=
pe Such felipe.such@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> a =C3=A9crit :
=

>
>
> Hi Rihab,
>
> Congrats on the results!
>
> The robustness seem to be=
 a common problem when being greedy. We noticed
> that picking the agent wi=
th THE highest score ever was resulting on poor
> median scores, but overal=
l the evolving population was still producing
> individuals that are robust=
 to the no-ops. On our latest version we added a
> more robust elite select=
ion procedure that mitigates this issue.
>
> Best regard,
> Felipe
>
> On S=
un, Jun 3, 2018 at 5:06 AM, Rihab Gorsane rihab.gorsane@...
> [neat=
] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>>
>> [Attachment(s) <#m_6657121978590968=
681_m_2374212864787020521_TopText>
>> from Rihab Gorsane included below]
>>=

>>
>> Hi all,
>>  I am glad to share with you the results I got after runn=
ing my
>> distributed genetic implementation on Frostbite Atari game.
>>
>>=
 Due to the limited hardware resources I have (only available 36 CPU
>> cor=
es),  I fixed the population size to only 1000 individuals.
>> I stopped th=
e training after 100 generations because waiting to reach 1B
>> frames cost=
s a lot of time. These 100 generations proceeded about 321402808
>> frames.=

>> I saved  the Highest performing model every 50 generation:
>> At genera=
tion 50, the best model scored 4490 and at generation 100 the
>> best model=
 scored 5350 which is considered a very exciting result as far as
>> I know=
.
>>
>> There is something that is not clear to me:
>> I have followed the =
paper baselines for no-op operations but I noticed
>> that the agent is not=
 robust at random starts ( the median at generation
>> 100 was 180)
>> I am=
 wondering if anyone could clarify this for me or tell me if this
>> proble=
m is also encountered in your implementation.
>>
>> Thank you,
>> Best rega=
rds,
>> =E1=90=A7
>>
>> 2018-05-30 9:46 GMT+01:00 Rihab Gorsane <rihab.gors=
ane@...>:
>>
>>> Thank you Felipe,
>>>
>>> Best regards,
>>>
>>> 20=
18-05-30 0:19 GMT+01:00 Felipe Such felipe.such@... [neat] <
>>> neat@=
yahoogroups.com>:
>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>> Hi Rihab,
>>>>
>>>> Feel free to reach=
 out with any questions, we are glad people are
>>>> interested on the pape=
r and reproducing it's results.
>>>> We are using NoFrameskip-v4. We follow=
 the same preprocessing steps as
>>>> other methods (Example:
>>>> https://=
github.com/openai/baselines/blob/master/baselines/common/atari_wrappers.py)=
.
>>>> We use the accumulated reward (no discount factor, no clipping).
>>>=
> You are right on the 20k frames limit as it translates to 5k timesteps
>>=
>> after the frame skips.
>>>>
>>>> Best regard,
>>>> Felipe
>>>>
>>>> On T=
ue, May 29, 2018 at 1:59 AM, Rihab Gorsane
>>>> rihab.gorsane@... [=
neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> Hi all,
>>>>>
>>=
>>> I've begun reproducing the DeepNeuroevolution paper in Pytorch. I've
>>=
>>> considered only the Atari case study to test my algorithm on.
>>>>> In =
the paper, it's mentioned that "During training, each agent is
>>>>> evalua=
ted on a full episode (capped at 20k frames), which can include
>>>>> multi=
ple lives and fitness is the final episode reward". Thus I think that
>>>>>=
 I need to track the number of frames each agent is proceeding and limit it=
s
>>>>> evaluation at 20k frames ( 5k frames for my case since I'm doing k=
=3D4 frame
>>>>> skipping technique for some games).
>>>>>
>>>>> I was wond=
ering if anyone could tell me which environment Uber was
>>>>> wrapping ( -=
v0 or -v4, doing frame skipping or not) and also for the
>>>>> reward, are =
they just picking the last reward as the fitness score or
>>>>> calculating=
 the accumulated reward or doing some reward clipping.
>>>>>
>>>>> Thank yo=
u,
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>
>>>
>>
> 
>

      <p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Rihab,<div><br></div><div>Con=
grats on the results!</div><div><br></div><div>The robustness seem to be a =
common problem when being greedy. We noticed that picking the agent with TH=
E highest score ever was resulting on poor median scores, but overall the e=
volving population was still producing individuals that are robust to the n=
o-ops. On our latest version we added a more robust elite selection procedu=
re that mitigates this issue.</div><div><br></div><div>Best regard,</div><d=
iv>Felipe</div></div><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><div class=3D"gmail_quo=

=
      
      <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Rihab,<div><br></div><div>Feel free=
 to reach out with any questions, we are glad people are interested on the =
paper and reproducing it's results.</div><div>We are using NoFrameskip-=
v4. We follow the same preprocessing steps as other methods (Example: <a hr=
ef=3D"https://github.com/openai/baselines/blob/master/baselines/common/atar=
i_wrappers.py" target=3D"_blank" rel=3D"noreferrer">https://github.com/open=
ai/baselines/blob/master/baselines/common/atari_wrappers.py</a>). We use th=
e accumulated reward (no discount factor, no clipping).<br></div><div>You a=
re right on the 20k frames limit as it translates to 5k timesteps after the=
 frame skips.</div><div><br></div><div>Best regard,</div><div>Felipe<br></d=
iv></div><div><div class=3D"m_6657121978590968681m_2374212864787020521m_356=
9974043165448771h5"><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><div class=3D"gmail_quot=
